subject: Re: [junit] Auto-generating AllTests.java for each package?
msgSnippet: ... I like per-project test suites because I ve written a custom Javadoc taglet for package.html files which will run that package s test suite from within the
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> jason r tibbetts wrote:
>
>>Jason Rogers wrote:
>> > On 12/16/2005 11:20 AM, jason r tibbetts apparently said:
>> >
>> >
>> >>I've been on an XDoclet kick lately, and I'm considering writing a
>> >>custom XDoclet task that will automatically generate an AllTests class
>> >>for each package. Has anyone already done this, or is there a similar,
>> >>non-XDoclet solution? It can be easily done by any scripting language,
>> >>but I have an ulterior motive to using XDoclet--I'm looking for a simple
>> >>example to use in tutorials and presentations.
>> >
>> >
>> > JUnit-Addons has the DirectoryBuilder which we use on our projects. It
>> > doesn't produce an AllTests class but it produces a suite on the fly.
>>
>>I use junit-addons, but I hadn't paid much attention to that class
>>before. But you'd still have to create an AllTests class and use the
>>DirectorySuiteBuilder to create the suite()'s return value, and I'm too
>>lazy to do even that for each package that I create.
>
>
> Why do it per package? Do it once for the whole project.
>
> That said, I've never seen an XDoclet solution to generating AllTests.

I like per-project test suites because I've written a custom Javadoc
taglet for package.html files which will run that package's test suite
from within the Javadoc documentation. Why? Because our group has a
common code repository that gets submissions from our various
subprojects, and providing things like embedded test runners in the
documentation is a /very/ handy way to demonstrate how a given package
or class works. I've created many other Javadoc taglets along the same
lines, such as for embedding code snippets, applets that demonstrate
library widgets, etc.
